corpus.description: Texts from Nuclear Threat Initiative website, created by Center for Non-Proliferation Studies
corpus.name: NTI

sentence.text: That lessens the chance of profitability and alarms the banks that have insisted on these sales .
My visit must have alarmed him to the extent that he decided to check again to ensure he had n't left any clues .
The brilliance of the recent verbal firework display he put on at Westminster enchanted his party -- just as it alarmed the Labour Party that John Smith proved such an easy target for him .
Rising oil prices , a result of the Gulf conflict , assured short-term gains in 1991 , but alarmed the government which had as its primary economic goal the increase of non-oil exports .
I thought them beautiful , but they clearly alarmed Mr Singh who was not used to my wife 's Celtic colouring .

This alarms others who are unimpressed by being able to order their groceries down the tube and remember the TV-eye in Orwell 's 1984 which spied on the populace as well as thundering propaganda messages at them .
It may perhaps be more difficult to alarm him than it would be to alarm the vulnerable persons whom the offence is principally designed to protect .
In fact , Bagshaw forced himself to recognise , although it alarmed him to do so , that in his own sphere Armstrong was the starriest name in the business .
He had developed a droning style of speaking , and the general appearance of sluggishness alarmed his friends .
Dotty 's way of life sometimes alarmed her friends .
His question about the bearded man alarmed her .
A spokesman for the Sports Council , which helped fund the study , said they were alarmed by the findings .
He was so alarmed by Mr Brownlow 's excitement that he fainted once more .
The government was seriously alarmed by an outbreak of unrest in April in the western Autonomous Region of Xinjiang Uygur .
Oh , dear , I should 've warned you , so you would n't be alarmed . "
MacDonald thought that it would further alarm the public if he cancelled his journey .
The empty echo of her voice alarmed her and she whispered his name instead .
In 1739 Woodrop and Colquhoun precipitated a minor crisis by refusing to tolerate Weir 's absenteeism any longer , and the former in fact greatly alarmed James Graham by threatening to resign .
The crisis moved world markets , alarmed the West and prompted President Bill Clinton to declare that Mr Yeltsin personally represented democratic and market reform in Russia .
These two events greatly alarmed the Western intelligence community .
